This is motivated by a discussion I had with @Peter Pfaffelhuber , who was surprised that we need EMetricSpace and not PseudoEMetricSpace for the space of values of the process to get the existence of a Hölder modification in the Kolmogorov-Chentsov theorem (for this theorem for example).

Why do we need the space to be metric, and not only pseudo-metric? Well, to obtain a modification YYY of a process XXX, such that for all ttt, Yt=XtY_t = X_tYt​=Xt​ a.e., we say that it suffices to show dE(Yt,Xt)=0d_E(Y_t, X_t) = 0dE​(Yt​,Xt​)=0 a.e. So this is the (first) reason, but then comes the question of what we can get in a pseudo-metric space. Can we get a "distance zero modification", such that dE(Yt,Xt)=0d_E(Y_t, X_t) = 0dE​(Yt​,Xt​)=0 a.e., or are we using metric elsewhere?
It turns out that we are currently using metric elsewhere.

When we build a Hölder modification for one exponent YtβY_t^\betaYtβ​, we also prove that it is a limit of XXX: we have Ytβ=lim⁡s∈T′,s→tXsY_t^\beta = \lim_{s \in T', s \to t} X_sYtβ​=lims∈T′,s→t​Xs​ (simplifying a bit). Same thing for YtγY_t^\gammaYtγ​ for another exponent. We then want to build a modification that is Hölder for both exponents, and for measurability reasons, the construction we use needs the pairs (Xsβ,Ytγ)(X_s^\beta, Y_t^\gamma)(Xsβ​,Ytγ​) to be measurable for all (s,t)(s, t)(s,t) (remember that we don't have a second-countable space, so measurability of the pair does not follow from the individual measurability alone).
The way we currently do it is roughly as follows: we know that (Xs,Xt)(X_s, X_t)(Xs​,Xt​) is measurable for all (s,t)(s,t)(s,t). We write (Ysβ,Ytγ)=(lim⁡s′∈T′,s′→sXs′,lim⁡t′∈T′,t′→tXt′)=lim⁡s′,t′∈T′,(s′,t′)→(s,t)(Xs′,Xt′)(Y_s^\beta, Y_t^\gamma) = (\lim_{s' \in T', s' \to s} X_s', \lim_{t' \in T', t' \to t} X_t') = \lim_{s',t' \in T', (s',t') \to (s,t)} (X_s', X_t')(Ysβ​,Ytγ​)=(lims′∈T′,s′→s​Xs′​,limt′∈T′,t′→t​Xt′​)=lims′,t′∈T′,(s′,t′)→(s,t)​(Xs′​,Xt′​) and that last limit is measurable. But here is the issue: the last equality uses the fact that the space is metric and not just pseudo-metric.

In a pseudo-metric space, say that ys(1)y_s^{(1)}ys(1)​ and ys(2)y_s^{(2)}ys(2)​ are at distance 0. Then if Xs′X_s'Xs′​ tends to ys(1)y_s^{(1)}ys(1)​ as s′s's′ tends to sss in T′T'T′, then it tends also to ys(2)y_s^{(2)}ys(2)​. The way the limit is defined in Lean is that it picks an arbitrary element among the possible limits.
Then we can have (lim⁡s′∈T′,s′→sXs′,lim⁡t′∈T′,t′→tXt′)=(ys(1),yt)(\lim_{s' \in T', s' \to s} X_s', \lim_{t' \in T', t' \to t} X_t') = (y_s^{(1)}, y_t)(lims′∈T′,s′→s​Xs′​,limt′∈T′,t′→t​Xt′​)=(ys(1)​,yt​) but lim⁡s′,t′∈T′,(s′,t′)→(s,t)(Xs′,Xt′)=(ys(2),yt)\lim_{s',t' \in T', (s',t') \to (s,t)} (X_s', X_t') = (y_s^{(2)}, y_t)lims′,t′∈T′,(s′,t′)→(s,t)​(Xs′​,Xt′​)=(ys(2)​,yt​) and the equality we used does not hold.

I'm curious about possible solutions to get to a distance zero modification that is Hölder for several exponents. I started trying to generalize in the draft PR https://github.com/RemyDegenne/brownian-motion/pull/300 and that's how I encountered the issue.
Naïve question: if d (X, Y) = 0 everywhere and X is measurable, is Y also measurable?
That would replace the equality of limits with the distance zero statement, and then we would transfer measurability that way, I see. I don't know the answer to that question yet, though.
The question is whether {a | Y a \in U} is measurable when U is open. But if d (X, Y) = 0 everywhere, X a belongs to U iff Y a does, so this set is {a | X a \in U}, so it is indeed measurable. Right?
Looks good. That's solved then. Thanks! :tada: I'll implement that.
